description: Yelp star was not encouraging but I trusted my friend's recommendation. I'm so glad I came. Delicious dim sum, clean, nice airy space, quick services. Lots of local Chinese people even in Tuesday. Nice comfort foods place. I'll be back!
author: Sayuri W.

description:
Beware of fraud - I used to visit this place regularly for a few dishes that I like.  However, their food and service are getting worse so I stopped eating here.  Over the weekend my wife and I just happened to be in the area so we decided to give it a try.  The food was okay but the waitress is still pretty unprofessional with the way she dealt with customers (to be fair, the second waitress seems to be okay with her interaction with other customers).  

Today I received my credit bill and noticed that they added $1 to the actual total amount.  At first I thought it was an honest mistake so I was going to let it go.  But then I realized that I had the same experience about 8 months ago at this restaurant where they added $0.50 to the total amount (after 15% tip).  I always keep my credit card receipts so I can verify all my charges from the statement.  If this happened to me twice, I am sure they must have done the same to other customers.  Even though it is a waste of my time for $1 dispute, I decided to call my credit card to report it.
author: David D.

description:
Stopped by here for lunch one day since this place has been a staple in the neighborhood for decades. 

Immediately noticed this place is really catered towards Chinese regulars. You are seated and given a sheet to fill out for dim sum items which is the usual for a lot of dim sum places. If you have questions about menu be prepared to ruin someone's day as asking about anything seems to be a burden to the staff/management.   

Most of the items are pretty basic with a little variation for stuff like shrimp dumplings etc. Everything we ordered was good but the wait time for each items was a bit long. 

We were a group of 4 persons and ran the bill up to about $60, we were adventurous and tried a lot of the menu. Over all we agreed that we would rather go to any of the many Dim Sum places in SF as the overall experience here was unwelcoming and lack luster. 

Notes:

-Food here is good
-Best if you can speak/read Chinese
-Parking can be a bit tough (Residential, or parking meters)
-Overall clean 
-Service is like stepping on toes
-Food comes out a bit slow

As with a 2 star rating per Yelp "Meh. I've experienced better."
author: Brian H.

description:
DO NOT GO HERE
The service is horrible, took forever to get any food out to us. The place is not clean at all, there were floaters in my water when I got it and the silverware was also dirty. The food had no taste and smelled rotten. I was expecting to get sick half way through. I was not happy with this experience and I suggest avoiding this restaurant.
author: Liz J.

description: This dim sum is pretty good. Happy hour has good pricing. My favorite is the shrimp dumplings.
author: Dan P.

description:
The food here is good. Some of it is really good.

That being said, for the reasons stated below in many other reviews, I *only* come here when I'm with my Chinese best friend. There are a lot of Chinese people eating here, you will notice, so obviously the food is at least decent (I really love the fried chicken and get it every time...it's seasoned well and crunchy on the outside and juicy on the inside). I have noticed that, as others have mentioned, I do get stared at by the Chinese patrons when we're there (I'm not Chinese) but that's fine. We've had many lunches here together and come away full for less than $25 every time.

I would never come here without her! Now that she doesn't live a block away, I haven't come in quite a while. And judging by the reviews below, I know that I probably won't patronize this place again for a long time. It's really sad that they treat their customers this way. I can overlook that it's not that clean (most Chinese restaurants in the City aren't, let's face it), but thievery is just downright unacceptable. Period.
author: Theresa C.

description: I enjoyed having dim sum there. It was a little strange that there was a huge back of the restaurant but we were seated in the front. It seemed weird to separate the restaurant like this as the flow of service would have worked better if we were with the people in the far back of the restaurant but we were in the front by ourselves. The food was good and the sesame balls were HUGE!
author: Josh H.

description: This place is easy to find. Located on Clement Street. The service was very fast though no one spoke English so I had to point at pictures. The flavors in the foods and the textures were wonderful. The portion sizes were very large. The price is very reasonable if you're on a budget. I recommend this dim sum. But be prepared to do your own translation. It was a bit on the noisy side when they answer the phone they start yelling in it. I don't think I saw anyone in the whole place smile. Food prices, flavor, and potion size were awesome.
author: Thomas B.

description: I got a dirty chipped plate that had a glob of dried food residue.  Not a good start.  Asked for a replacement which they brought out but it should have never happened in the first place.  We ordered dim sum and chicken feet.  All the skins on the dim sum were so mushy they disintegrated while trying to get them out of the basket.  Chicken feet were all totally too mushy, although the taste was good.  Pot stickers totally mushy on the inside - not good.  The servers and the hostess seemed all to be very unhappy to be there.   Also was harassed by a couple of irritating little flies while I was eating.  I gave the extra star because at least our waiter saw that the teapot we had was leaking like a sieve and replaced it without having to be asked to do so.  Not going back.  This is a one and done for me.
author: Johnson E.

description: If you are looking for a restaurant with friendly, courteous staff and great food this is NOT the place to go. To begin with, they didn't offer any drinks, when we asked for the dim sum menu she crossed the prices off the menu in front of us and changed them for higher ones. When we asked questions they were annoyed and didn't respond or gave the shortest possible answer. We were the only ones there at the time so there was no rush or any reason to be annoyed. The food was ok but it was very unpleasant every time they approached the table with the long, grumpy face and attitude. To top it off they got the order wrong and they didn't even apologize. Terrible experience.
author: Josie G.

description:
I'm mad at myself for not reading the Yelp reviews before eating here! We were super hungry after wandering around Clement and decided to stop in for some quick dim sum. Immediately we were stared at by the staff and other customers in the restaurant which continued through our entire meal. We were given two menus for three people and asked about the dim sum menu when we saw the waitress again 15 minutes later. She brought over a menu with prices crossed out in pencil and rewritten as more expensive, looks like certain customers get cheaper prices here. A different waitress brought a plate of wakame and showed us saying you like seaweed? We looked at the plate and said we didn't order that and didn't want it.

After about 30 minutes we finally flagged the waitress down as she was coming out of the kitchen with another table's free chicken feet that seemed to be given to every table except ours. We ordered and 15 minutes later they told me sister they didn't have chow fun, so she would need to get chow mein. Mid bite into the chow mein we found a metal thread! It was sharp and most likely from a wire dish scrubbing brush. We told the waitress and she said oh its probably from the dishes. The dumplings were okay, the sesame balls were the best part of the meal but due to the bad service we will never be back and I hope the health department will sort this place out.
author: Lisa H.

description: I live around the neighborhood and my family usually goes to Hong Kong Lounge on Geary, but if we want quick dim sum with no line, we usually just go here. This place virtually has no line on weekdays for dim sum and the pricing is really good. $2.65 for all normal dim sum dishes (whether small medium or large). Dim sum goes till 3pm. The quality I feel like isn't as good as some other places (like HK Lounge and Dragon Beaux which is also nearby), but you can't beat the cheap prices! Yes, the staff can be somewhat rude.. And occasionally forget a dish you ordered... But I find it a lot easier going with Chinese speakers. My dad isn't afraid to talk back to the servers (in a rather playful manner) when they basically forgot one of our dishes.
author: Meagan C.

description: Dim sums taste wounderful with reasonable prices.  Unfortunately, the waitress don't communicate well with English
author: Patrick L.

description: I use to come here a lot to buy the dim sum. it is still good and the pork buns I just bought had a lot of meat and not a lot of bread which is good . it was crazy crowded and not cheap but worth it if the pork buns were this good .
author: Nellie J.

description: We had a wonderful time eating at Golden Gate.   Dim sum was good, hot, had many different dishes.   Services was also good.   Price was very reasonable.
author: John W.

description: It's probably one of the cheapest dim sum places in the city.  The downside is the food is inconsistent.  I've had days when food seems super fresh and flavorable.  Other times it can be tasteless and a bit stale.  But it's a great go to if you want a quick tea time to chat etc.  Not the cleanest nor the dirtiest Chinese restaurant around.  Right in the middle.....
author: Ben L.

description:
Be careful of this place.  They may charge you more by manually changing the prices on the dim sum menu to be $1.00 higher than the list price.  Other customers that understand Chinese may get their printed listed price, no scratching off the prices on the menu.  Look around at other tables to see if they got the same prices.  This is how I caught them.  When I confronted the cashier, she got defensive that I have another table's menu with the list price and said the price on our menu was for dinner...then why do you give me the dinner price when I was there at 12:30pm for lunch?

After sharing our experience to other family members, they too almost got ripped off until they confronted the cashier as to why the bill was so much higher.  If you eat there, be sure to get an itemized bill that shows the items ordered so that you can reconcile the charge to what you ordered, otherwise they will overcharge you.

I will not be going back to this place.  If you want dim sum and don't need to sit down to eat it, there are other dim sum take-out stores on Clement between 6th & 8th Avenue that is only around $2.10 per order vs $2.80 (list price) or $3.80 (the claimed dinner price or ripping people off).

It's a shame that these people are dishonest.
author: Clem Y.

description:
I can excuse a brusque attitude, chalk up flies around the front door as trash having been recently cleared and overlook a scuffed up appearance inside and out but I can't excuse watching an employee squat on the floor 15 feet behind the register shucking produce (I saw this when I returned to pick up the order I'd already paid for) nor mushy shrimp in my entree that announces it was one step away from being composted.

After 2 bites, I threw away my honey walnut prawn entree and had one too many bites of very fatty pork hidden beneath the sweet & sour sticky sauce.

The dim sum was just ok: the wrappers were too thick and the ha gow once again tasted on the verge of spoiled (loads of garlic and spinach didn't disguise the gooey texture of the chopped shrimp inside).

Skip this place; given their lousy attitude, they won't miss you.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
SCAM ARTISTS - READ YOUR CHECK FOR CORRECT $ BEFORE PAYING

I came here to get dim sum with my friend. Each item was 3-4 dollars plus a little veggie spinach dish. I was expecting a check for about $28-30. Check comes, $47. I ask the waitress to give me an itemized check. She starts double talking about tips being included, etc. I grab the dim sum menu and calculate how much it is on my phone. Comes out to about $22. Waitress then claims the small veggie dish was $16.95. I look at the menu online, the veggie dish is $7.95, very basic Chinese veggie, nothing special. Oh, also, apparently the tea on the table is $2 per person, never seen that charge in a Chinese restaurant before. I demand they refund my money and give me a check with the actual amount owed. I was really annoyed at this point and the waitress finally did it because I raised a stink. I'll never ever ever go back there. Shame on them for ripping people off. 

Coming to Yelp I now see these also have health violations. Gross to know since I just ate there 2 hours ago.
author: M K.

description:
Sometimes on the weekends, I crave dim sum but I'm too lazy to go out and wait for a table. In comes Golden gate dim sum seafood restaurant to the rescue. Dim sum delivery at reasonable prices! Some restaurants deliver dim sum, but at much higher prices, so you can't order everything you want. At Golden gate, you can! I typically order from their website. Previous orders have included:

February 2013:
Egg rolls ($2)
Steamed beef balls ($2)
Taro cake with chinese sausage ($2)
Deep fried stuffed dumplings ($2)
Steamed chicken feet ($2)
Steamed pork dumplings ($2)
Steamed pork spareribs ($2)
Steamed house dumplings ($2.50)
House steamed shrimp dumplings ($2.50)
Steamed pea sprout dumplings ($2.50)
Steamed stuffed tofu skin rolls ($2.50)
Shrimp rice noodle rolls ($3)
Sticky rice with lotus leaf ($3)
Steamed beef tripe ($4.50)
Beef tripe with turnip ($4.50)

December 2012:
Pan fried turnip cake ($2)
Steamed pork dumplings ($2)
Steamed egg custard bun ($2)
Steamed bbq pork bun ($2)
Steamed beef balls ($2)
Pan fried pot stickers ($2.50)
Steamed Shanghai dumplings ($2.50)
House steamed shrimp dumplings ($2.50)
Steamed scallops dumplings ($2.50)
Steamed stuffed tofu skin rolls ($2.50)
Shrimp rice noodle rolls ($3)
Sticky rice with lotus leaf ($3)
Steamed beef tripe ($4.50)
Clam with black bean sauce ($4.50)
Shrimp dumpling soup ($4.50)
FREE Chicken chow mein

Their dim sum is pretty average. The staple dishes such as the har gow, shu mai, chicken feet, spareribs, noodle rolls, sticky rice in lotus leaf, etc are good enough to satisfy my dim sum craving when I'm too lazy to go out. And for the prices, I can still order all the dishes I want! 3 stars for the food, but bumping it up to 4 stars since they deliver!
author: Elena N.

description: Worst rudest lady taking my order!  super expensive. While paying instead of handing me my change she threw it to the side !  Food is so so.
author: Amy S.

description:
This place is on the lower end of dim sum places that I've had in San Francisco. While there are a lot of people who frequent this restaurant (largely locals, I'm assuming), the quality and service at this place is extremely subpar. Most of the food items were fairly low quality (either too oily or cold) and the prices were pretty high for food that you can find for much cheaper elsewhere in the city. 

Your best bet is to go somewhere else if you're craving dim sum.
author: Josh C.

description:
My family and I came here during a holiday in search for some dim sum. Initially, we were heading towards Hong Kong Lounge but after seeing the line, we decided to go elsewhere. And that's how we were brought here. I actually just found this place by mistake. 

I was lured in by the shorter line & pricing. We waited a few minutes to be seated. I was so surprised to see that the dishes were so cheap! From $2.50-$3.25!!! Specialty dishes were priced at $5.50...but not bad.

The restaurant was packed! So I was assuming it was good. So we marked on the little paper provided ehat we wanted and gave it to the waitress. 

Service:

It's really not the best. They sorta ignore you and have to wave them down for something. I had to ask 3 times for my water to come. The guy was pretty attentive though when clearing our dishes. But we waited 20-25mins for our food to come out. Idk if it was because it was a holiday?

Food:

* Siumai: Standard. A little smaller than usual but served hot. Also it was pretty moist. 
* Har Gow: Good size. The skin was a little sticky but othereise delicious. 
* Chicken Feet (NOT PICTURED): Was tender yet had an overpowering anise flavor. But not bad for the price.
* Shrimp and Chive: Delicious filling but the wrapper was also sticky. We finished it though.
* Fried Shrimp Dumpling: A little greasy. But otherwise standard.
* Steamed Spareribs: I've had better. But it cured my craving.
* Sticky Rice in Lotus Leaf (NOT PICTURED): Lots of filling. Served hot.
* Steamed Tofu Roll (NOT PICTURED): Kept falling apart. Not too much flavor.
* Fried Sesame Ball  (NOT PICTURED): Good but a little softer than I'm used to. A little greasy as well.
* Fried Shrimp Roll (NOT PICTURED): Ehh. Greasy. Slightly burnt.
* Foil Wrapped Chicken: I guess I'm not a big fan of five-spice. The chicken was moist though.

Overall I would come back if I was in the area and Hong Kong Lounge had a long line again. Not the best dim sum in the world but it also depends on what you order. I loved how the dishes were always served hot. Not bad for a quick fix. Pretty cheap too. All of the dishes ee ordered rounded up to $39.
author: Ralph N.

description:
This is without a doubt, my least favorite restaurant in the city. My gringo presence there elicits stares as if i was a lost tourist in a favela. 

You will be greeted tersely by a quick tongued waitress who will seat you on an unkempt table. You will order. You will wait. You will remind them. You will wait. You will note a cook kicking unused vegetables under the oven. You will wait. 

God willing, you will eventually get your food. The shrimp dumplings might be decent. Everything else conjures up melancholy adolescent memories of endless overcast weather, sadness and shame. 

Eventually you'll get the bill. Everything is in Chinese except for total. For gods sake don't leave a tip. 

Speaking of which, here's a tip: go Dragon Beau, Hong Kong noodles, Ton Kiang or especially Shanghai Dumpling King. They'll all far higher quality, similar price, and you'll be treated like an actual living breathing person. 

More details: 
- they have no posted credit card minimum, but you'll get lots of shade for pulling one out. 

- shrimp dumplings are the only thing worth ordering. 

- don't be afraid to ask for a translated receipt. 

- serious this place is awful. If I didn't live 40 ft away I would never have gone.
author: Johnnycakes F.

description:
Long waits, no parking & they forgot one of my orders...

My parents say this is one of the better dim sum restaurants in the city, but in my opinion they all kind of taste the same... I wouldn't recommend coming on the weekends, because there are a ton of families waiting to eat and they have this number system that doesn't even work!! They call out the wrong numbers/only call numbers inside so if you're standing outside you don't hear it... 

As for the food, it comes out pretty quickly, but the last time I came, they forgot one of our orders!! So we were sitting there for maybe... 20 minutes without any food and a running meter!! We ended up just canceling the order and getting the check cause we didn't wanna waste our quarters anymore
author: Carrie L.

description:
I've been here at least 5 times as it's in the heart of the Richmond - where you'll find a plethora of dim sum establishments. This is perhaps one of the most underrated dim sum places in S.F. as you'll find the QUALITY of some dishes comparable to those in Hong Kong Lounge for significantly less expensive. Sure, there is less selection but if you're looking for a solid place for dim sum, definitely check this place out!

Shrimp rice noodle - the noodles are cooked perfectly, not overly thick nor thin.
Shrimp and chives dumpling - my favorite
Sticky rice wrapped in lotus leaf - super flavorful

Service is lacking as you'll more likely than not have to ask for utensils, refills, etc- otherwise efficient.
author: Carol W.

description:
I wouldn't eat is this place again, I found it really dirty, I dont think the waitress spoke English at all, the Egg rolls we ordered were really greasy, we complained and ask her to take it off our  bill and we can order something else, she said no, cant do that, I really think she didn't understand why we were complaining and held up the egg roll with grease dripping from it, No Customer service her, we order Shrimp and Lobster sauce, Not bad but nothing outstanding, along with a shrimp and rice dish, dry and not impressed, all and all it was not a good restaurant, so pass it by....I hate dirty and Greasy, we were praying we didn't get sick, we didn't,
 but stay away...
author: Ronne M.

description: I loved this place.... Until we decided to order a second round of shrimp dumpling(ha gaw). Had to ask twice, so when it came and I picked it up, a cooked cockroach surprise was waiting for me... Completely under and cooked underneath the ha gaw. Then the bf got stomach flu just 3-4 days right after.
author: Sappho C.

description: Waitress wasn't friendly, the place was sticky and dirty, the food tasted like pure salt, the appetiser came out after our main dishes. Found a hair in my food, wasn't cheap. I won't be back.
author: Ari M.

description: This little out of the way gem is a must. Steamed pork buns were so tender. Steamed egg custard a treat. Chicken wings nice a crispy. You must try.
author: Colleen P.

description: Yes, it is tasty food but, ahem, $100 for lunch for 3 with tea was exceptionally expensive. Beware the immediate presentation of seaweed salad or other unsolicited first plate as soon as you are seated - next was the hassle of accepting or rejecting bok choy or broccoli. I said combine the two but our server said not a good idea so we ended up with 2 plates of vegetables for $9.95 each! Yeah, good food, but no, we probably won't be back...
author: Steve D.

description: Don't even bother with this place. I have tried to order from here a few times. They do not respond. Also do not, and I repeat do NOT use eat24 to place your order because they will not complete the order. Feel free to go in and check it out, but do not order delivery if you expect to get food
author: Grace H.

description:
After going to New Hing Lung several times for dinner just to eat their clay pot rice... Now it was time for me to move on to another chinese restaurant that has clay pot rice... And now for my next adventure for clay pot rice and this time... I ended up at Golden Gate Dim Sum Seafood Restaurant of clement st... Came here for lunch on a over cast weather on a monday which was a perfect time to have me some clay pot rice as soon as I got seated quickly by the hostess in which it was just me... Which means a table for one and that would be me!!! As soon as the waitress handed me the lunch menu and when I saw the clay pot rice on the menu... You know what that means that's what I'll be eating not only did the clay pot rice I also ordered some Steamed Shanghai Dumplings and since its my day off!!! I gotta have me a Tsingtao Beer just to have me some fun on The Chinese New Year Of The Horse 2014!!! And yes if you yelpers have seen my posted pictures of my clay pot rice & steamed shanghai dumplings and also one Tsingtao Beer... I finished it all with my very very hungry appetite!!! Now that it was my very very 1st time being at the Golden Gate Dim Sum Seafood Restaurant... I have to say that the hostess and the waitresses that were working there were all very friendly and helpful on the things... That I have asked for!!!
Since no one from yelp has posted Clay Pot Rice Pictures... I am the first yelper to post a picture of the Yummy Clay Pot Rice!!! Don't drool on it now LOL!!!
author: William B.

description:
I had such a bad experience with this restaurant. We were hungry and didn't have a car at the time so decided to walk down the street to see what restaurants we could find there. Then we saw dim sum and seafood, so dim sum it is. 
I didn't check Yelp until after we placed the order and I really wish I checked before going in. (Poor safety score is an obvious enough sign already... But I was secretly hoping maybe it meant the food would be good lol.) 
We got har gow, beef rice noodle rolls, egg yolk buns, spring rolls and Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce to go. The total came up to be around $25 which wasn't bad in SF. The lady who took our order didn't even offer to give me a receipt. And I never got a receipt. 
Waited for about 25 minutes for our order and I asked if they had chopsticks for takeouts. Nope, plastic forks only. Okay, no big deal. 
So when we finally started eating, I was so disappointed. 
According to my friend, the har gow was average and doughy. 
The Chinese broccoli was not even cut, I couldn't use the little plastic fork to pick it up and I had to use my hands to eat. They only gave us a tiny container of oyster sauce too, so for the most part this dish tasted flavorless. 
My all time favorite beef rice noodle rolls... I could barely taste beef in it. 
Egg yolk buns were small but looked nice. However when I took a bite, I just saw oil coming out from the bun and the whole thing just tasted like fat. 
Spring rolls looked sad, burned and soggy. They tasted soggy and greasy, too. Should've went to Panda Express for spring rolls instead lol. 
Never going back and won't recommend this place to anyone.
author: Jane L.

description:
This place is open on Sunday morning for dim sum!!! There is an error on Yelp and Google that says it is closed today. Anyways....we have wanted to eat here for years and we were not disappointed. 7 plates and $29 later, we left happy :) we tried:

Fried chicken wings (you can pass on these)
Pan fried pork with veggie bun (out of this world!!)
Pan fries chives dumpling
Steamed shrimp dumpling (this was ok)
Pan fried pot stickers (amazing)
Steamed BBQ pork buns (delish)
Stuff crab claws with shrimp

This place is amazing. Come here. Avoid the hour wait at hong kong lounge. Oh, and it is cheap. My Chinese heritage tells me you should never pay more than $5 for dumplings like you do at the ridiculous trendy places...unless you're getting married.
author: Kuanie J.

description: Average dim sum, prices are very reasonable.  There were 3 adults and 1 child. Total bill was $26 bucks... we were completely stuffed! The best was the rice crepe noodles with different fillings.  Fast service,  usually a wait for tables.  Come back for the rice crepe!
author: Alicia A.

description: There was a baby cockroach in my shrimp dumpling. They apologized and we left. Don't eat here. If you do decide to eat here anyways, bring an enemy with you so they can be sick as well.
author: Cliff D.

description: I like the food. The dim sum is good, the chow mein is good. I've gone quite a few times. The reason they're getting 2 stars is the last 2 times I've gone they've overcharged me. You know the saying, "fool me once, shame on you, fool me twice shame on me." First time didn't catch it until later, today caught it right away. Thought I'd give them second chance after first time, but after today I'm not coming back. Too many other places that are good that I can go and have good dim sum that don't cheat you.
author: Ken T.

description: Ordered the fried squash dish and found plastic inside. Don't know what types of chemicals are in the food now.
author: Justin Y.

description: First of all, don't have any expectations when you're coming here. There was no wait when we came and the restaurant was about half full with customers. Their dim sum list was pretty limited compare to other dim sum places. We order the usual dim sum dishes like the shrimp dumplings and steamed custard buns. The food was about average, it wasn't something that would stand out. Their tea was very water down and flagging down a waiter was like a game. I understand most Asian restaurants don't have good service but this one was one of those you might as well get up and grab things yourself.
author: Lynn H.

description:
Eating here was the absolutely worst experience that I have ever had in a San Francisco restaurant. Just walk further up Clement or to Geary to some place else, especially if you are not natively Chinese.

1. Absolutely horrendous service - "it's a traditional Chinese dim sum hole in the wall" is not an excuse. It's also not okay for the only person who speaks English to be pugnatious with a horrible attitude and completely dishonest.

2. They will charge you inaccurately.

3. When you dispute it, they will bring back a bill with things you didn't order added on to justify the charges.

Normally, I like to patronize the smaller places around Richmond, but if I could, I would report this place for illegal business practices. It leaves a bad taste in your mouth.
author: R R.

description:
Fantastic!

After living  in Asia for 20 years hard to find local authentic dim sum but not here, it's the real deal. 

Dim Sum fresh, hot, tasty, and cheap. The rice noodles, wonton skin, and, steam dumplings not sticky great texture. Steam buns good proportion with dough and fillings. 

Service friendly but very authentic ( don't take it personal if they don't smile at you) and feel at home yelling for their attention. 

Atmosphere, burbing out loud from other tables is a good sign and compliment..feel free to let it go from the attic not the basement.


Great job and keep it real...you win some and you lose dim sum...this place a winner.

Xie Xie
author: Cesar L.

description:
Good:
Shu Mai
Tofu skin - 29
Foil chicken
Order ahead with picture so you don't have to wait for the right cart to come by
Food is hot (mostly) as its made to order

Bad:
Beef ribs
Steamed pork ribs
Slow to move tables

I'm okay with waiting a bit for the good as that's what dimsum is about, relax and drink tea.  But they can be faster at taking your order and getting you seated when there are unbussed tables

Good thing is, $2.50 for all dimsum!
author: Lusi F.

description: It's a good value dim sum place. The dishes come out steaming hot which is how dim sum should be. Not microwave hot. There's a difference, especially if it comes along w/a sauce. They refill the teapot & collects the empty dishes consistently during the luncheon. The host gets involve w/ the serving.  Everything came in a well timely manner ending w/ the bill. $10 per person w/ excess food so each had a take out box to take home. There may be a slight wait at times to get in during lunch. Satisfies my dim sum fix & walking distance.
author: M L.

description: Non-Asians beware.  We were charged a dollar more for each menu item while other diners were not. When the bill came she overcharged us by a considerable amount. When confronted with the discrepancy she tried to justify a $10 difference by the cost of the tea (which was just brought to table but not ordered). Service was nonexistent we practically had to go to kitchen to bring out our own food. We were either ignored or treated rudely. In the end the food wasn't that good either.
author: Matt G.

description:
The place was a dump. I really do not see anything good about this place. Came here the other day for dinner and it was a disappointment after another. The set menu should had everything, but didn't so had to order stuff instead. So we ordered the food and the soup was the first to come out, ad it tasted like salty beef with bok choy. We order some other meats and tofu and they weren't flavored enough, the only thing that was flavored enough was the vegetable plate which was overly salty. 

Dessert came around and it was a watered down black sesame soup, could see and feel the black bean paste, but only tasted water. The restroom was even upstairs and was nasty. When we waiting for the check and to endure the people smoking outside because the wind blew their smoke right inside their broken doors.
author: M C.

description:
My whole life I grew up on dim sum.  We headed to Chinatown every week and ate at one of those huge tea houses way back when.  They used to count the plates at the end of our meal before the whole stamp system came along.  Carts were the norm.  

These days, tiny restaurants can also service those looking for dim sum without all the fuss.  As a result, there are no carts being pushed and instead, you have a menu that you pencil in how many of each item you want.  (Good for those who know their dim sum, bad for newbies.)  

What makes Golden Gate Dim Sum a great steal?  Their Monday through Friday (10:30 am to 3:00 pm) dim sum prices at $1.90/plate.  These account for their small, medium, and large plates.  My retired parents know all about these places and frequent them quite a bit.  Word gets around at the senior centers.  They know they want to be seated downstairs, and they have to ask that all the food not come out at once.  (Yes, a bit too over efficient in this case.)

Our party of three: 

* Steamed Pork Dumplings ($2)
* Deep Fried Stuffed Dumplings ($2)
* Steamed Beef Balls ($2)
* Pan Fried Turnip Cake ($2)
* Steamed Chicken Feet ($2)
* Vegetable Dumplings ($2.50)
* Steamed Shrimp Dumplings ($2.50)
* Steamed Shanghai Dumplings ($2.50)
* Pan Fried Chives Dumplings ($3)
* Mushroom Tofu Skin Rolls ($3)
* Beef Rice Noodle Rolls ($3)
* Sticky Rice with Lotus Leaf ($3)

Nothing that really stood out as far as I recall.  It's dim sum, and it's cheap.  Service is standard, nothing special here.  It works when you're hungry on a weekday.  As least you know the food will come out quickly!
author: Teri C.

description:
Smaller, outdated decor Dim Sum place. Nothing that will make you say OMFG awesome, but also a place that won't kill your wallet.

Small, Medium and Large Dim Sum are $2 on weekdays and $2.25 on weekends - wowzer!

Price - 5 Stars
Food quality/taste 3 stars
Service - 4 Stars

We got 11 plates for 3 people:

fried shrimp ball - excellent and yummytastic
tofu skin meat wrap - excellent
fish rice noodle - good, but where's the fish :0
beef rice noodles - good
pork rice noodles - good
pork spareribs - good
shrimp dumpling - good filling, but skin was too sticky
vegatrian dumpling - pass - I need meat :P
fried egg custard bun - yummy
lotus sticky rice - excellent
fried salt/pepper chicken wings - ok, but crispy enough
author: Peter L.

description:
Having had dimsum all over the world I looked up and saw an article as one of the best dim sum places. After picking up my friend from the airport  (her first time visiting sf) we decided to come here for dimsum ummm we both agree it's the worse dimsum we have ever had :( anything fried all tasted of that burnt oil and well we couldn't bother to eat it so paid and left it lol not worth the calories or nauseated feeling :/ 

As for service couldn't tell if there was any but I never expect it from an Asian restaurant lol
author: Sharon L.

description: So many other good dim sum places around the area. I came here because there's no wait and it wasn't too busy. I had a couple of noodle dishes. Those were pretty good. However, the dim sum was another story. The rice noodle tasted pretty bland. The filling inside didn't feel too fresh. There wasn't anything special about any of the dim sum. Also, one of the shu mai had a bug in it. They were nice enough to exchange it though, so I'll give them that.
author: Arnold W.

description: Cheap prices, but barely passable dim sum.  I have no desire to come back.  They've not offended me in any way in particular, so this isn't grounds for a 1-star review.  Given all the other dim sum places in the area, i have no idea how this place stays open, frankly.
author: Leo C.

description:
I've been here a few times with my grandparents since it's their default dim sum place. Grandma says that if you know the waiters, they'll give you extra napkins. HAHA.

I'm generally not too picky about my dim sum. t's decently priced compared to other restaurants and tastes ok. It's not the best, but it's not terrible. As long has I have my ha gow, I'm a happy camper. I am still trying to find their wu gok (deep fried taro with meat filling) on their paper menu though. One day... one day.

Typically, on a weekday they're not too busy, so you can get seated fairly quickly. If they are busy, they have a good amount of tables, so you never have to wait too long.
author: Kathy L.

description:
I don't care how good the food is, it is NOT okay to make someone that isn't Cantonese wait an hour for take-out (couple items) in a non-peak hour while you serve every Cantonese person immediately after they walk in. That just doesn't fly in America. 

Be pushy and demanding here or they won't give you your food or respect you. Or just don't eat here at all.
author: Ryan G.

description:
I am reeeeally excited to yelp about this place! I was DONE waiting hours at Hong Kong Lounge and decided to find another dim sum place. I did a yelp for "dim sum" and found this joint. I walked around the corner and BAM I was here with NO WAIT! This place was 3 stars but I decided to try anyway. 

This restaurant has a pleasant decor with a pretty garden in the back (if you look closely there's mops on the side, lol). The food was also decent (average to good dim sum), somethings were oookay but others definitely made me want to come back. 

Yay dishes: har gow, rice noodle rolls, fried glutinous balls with meat inside (Xián shu jio)

Ehh dishes: sui mai, custard buns (these were funky, it's as tho the center had salty eggs instead of egg custards), shanghai dumplings

This place is definitely a place people should try. It's cheap and decently priced and best of all... NO WAIT!! The people were nice and service was fast! This place gets four star overall!!
author: Jen L.

description: No crowds looking over your shoulder and waiting for you to leave.  No haughty waiter or waitress with an attitude.  No cringing at the total bill. No wait and the food was good.  What more can I ask for on New Year's Day at 11:00 a.m.!  The rice noodle with BBQ pork, salted fried squash, and steamed sesame mochi balls (actual steam coming out) were all my favorites.  Steamed taro cake had actual taro.  Next time I should tried the rice noodle with fried bread inside.  Saw two tables ordering that.  $13.95 for Lobster noodles.  Don't know how good, but the price is right.
author: Helen L.

description:
alright, i've given this place two chances now. both times i have tried to order delivery on a monday night around 7pm, and have had my orders canceled.

the first time they canceled my order because they were busy, which i understand, but the problem here is i wasn't informed promptly. they didn't call me, i only received an email 40 minutes after i placed my order, at almost 8pm. so i had to to order dinner from somewhere else, because by this point my corner shop was closed, and i didn't end up eating until around 8:45pm. 

the second time i tried to order delivery was about 45 minutes ago. i receive a call from an eat24 employee - not the restaurant itself - informing me the order minimum is $20 when their yelp page clearly says its $15. she asked me if i wanted to add something to my order to meet the minimum, needless to say i said "no, please cancel" because this is now the second time i've dealt with this place that won't even call their own customers who want to spend money with them. obviously, i will not be trying to order from this restaurant ever again. there are plenty of mediocre dim sum restaurants in the richmond/sunset area.
author: Shannon H.

description: Came here for dim sum because it was the closest place we could find. Overall, the food was just okay. Not my favorite dim spot place in SF...
author: Siv L.

description: I just saw the low food safety rating after dining on takeaway har gow. The food was awful. It tasted like it had been stored in a freezer for at least a month...gummy on the outside, smushy on the inside. I hope that I don't get sick tonight. Additionally, they bumped up the dim sum prices by one dollar per order. They crossed off the original price on the paper menu just as I entered the restaurant. Hmmmm???
author: Rebecca H.

description:
CHEAP DIM SUM!!

all the dim sum is of average quality.  the ha gau was not as juicy as ho mong kok's, nor was the skin as thin as good luck dim sum's.  siu mai was a little bit dry and definetely greasy too.  eggplant was undercooked.  cheurng fun was thick and not as smooth as dim sum king's.  our gok bo tea tasted like it was sitting near the bathroom and soaking up the smells.   the tofu skin rolls was pretty unique and awesome and probably my favorite dish of the meal.  

totally average non-memorable food, but hey!  what can i say?? it was all pretty decent food and in large amounts for super cheap!   i would defininetly come back here as a hungry hippo again!
author: Tina A.

description: My family went to try a new dim sum restarant and we went here. The food was ok but the service was shit and ive been to many asian restaraunts. When we asked what was in the rice roll filling she was annoyed and told to us to just eat it and see whats inside it. We sat by the back window that goes to a pond and in the corner of the windows were piles of rat shit and flies buzzing about and some landed on my plate    This restaraunt is not worth going to.
author: Kalvin N.

description:
Boy did that place leave a bad taste in my mouth. With I would have checked the yelp reviews first. For starters , we asked for the dim sum menu and saw our waitress( with pencil ) changing the pricing up fifty cents per item. We were a little annoyed at that but hey, it was only 50 cents and we were seated and craving dim sum. 
The food was just mediocre. We asked the waitress which item was which, no response on each round of food. Just to add we were one of three tables in the whole restaurant.
Here's the real disappointment. Our bill made no sense.  Scribbles ( with pencil ) of a mystery number x 5 equals 17? I asked her to clarify because our bill seemed extremely high for what we ordered , and no even number without change equals 17 when multiplied by 5. Instead of explaining she grabbed the bill and came back with a new one almost 20 dollars cheaper ! Guess we caught her adding in a tip or something( it was just a party of 2). We thought it was off when she dropped off the check she stood next to the table trying to rush us to take out money although we were still eating. 
Now this is the REAL kicker that is posted in several reviews I should have read. She ran each of our cards for an even $30. I asked my dining companion was the bill an even $60? The waitress took the itemized bill away which I asked to see again to realize she rounded up to an even number. I told her it wasn't an agrees upon price, I handed her my card for the amount of the bill. She rolled her eyes , and threw some change on my table. I am a restaurant manager so tipping is embedded in my soul but boy do I wish I didn't tip. 
Moral of the story : do not go here
author: brittany g.

description:
I personally don't like dim sum restaurants because they make lunch last forever! (So if you love dim sum, I suppose you could add a star to my rating)

Anywho, this particular time-waster has all the typical dim sums such as har gows and shui mais. They're actually pretty good dim sum. Fresh, soft dumpling skins, and their foods come out hot. The only problem I see with their menu is that all their foods are very typical and BORING. They don't have any special items or Chef Specials or anything. But I guess it's more important to have simple dishes done really well than to hide bad food with cool names. "Chef Special: Spring Flower Fresh Volcanic Lava Chicken Delight" Err.. Ok.

Oh and it's cool that their menu was also in English.

There's no wait even though I came here on a Sunday, in fact, I think it was Father's Day.
author: Athena L.

description:
Despite checking the yelp reviews and finding them to be largely negative, my friend I decided to go to this restaurant anyway after getting crowded out of the nearby Hong Kong Lounge. 

The first thing to note about this place is that it lacked the typical bustle of a dim sum restaurant, and we soon encountered a lot of resulting problems. We waited a long time for a table in this slightly uncomfortable and weirdly laid out restaurant. Once seated, waited for a while and we were eventually given one of the paper menus to fill out, but it was ten to fifteen more minutes before someone came to collect that, and another ten to fifteen minutes before our first dish arrived. 
The food was fine, on average. We had steamed pork buns that were fine but not the best, siu mai that were actually pretty great, mediocre Shanghai dumplings, mediocre stuffed eggplant, string beans that tasted good but ended up being deep fried despite our expectation that they would be stir fried or steamed,  decent egg custard buns, and some mediocre taro dumplings. That amount of food was $34 before tip.

Overall, not a great experience. We waited way too long for food that wasn't great and not that cheap. Try somewhere else.
author: Allxie C.

description: The food was okay. Not bad. Texture of dumpling wraps were rougher than other dim sum restaurants. But still edible. The prices am were great. All the dim sin dishes were the same price regardless of small, medium, or large side. Same price of $2.65 per dim sine everyday. I don't understand why the checklist menu list different prices on the different sizes. We were charged correctly at the everything $2.65 per dim sum price. They did charge use $1.00 per person for tea. They get a 3 star from because because the customer service attitude was rude. No need to talk to customers like we don't know what's going on. Especially since it was our first time eating there. Just because you know the menu and how everything works, doesn't mean all your new customers will know. Hell man... Event time they brought out a dish to our table, I would say thank you to which I don't even get a response. Just a toss I'd the dish on the table and waters walked off. Hard to believe the customer was nicer then the restaurant workers. If they were nicer... No... If they were minutely nice, I would have give them 4 stars.
author: Jack L.

description: Came here for the first time and the restaurant looked pretty dirty but because there's a bunch of people eating here, I didn't think too much about it. The dim sum was alright until we found a dead cockroach in our shrimp stuffed pepper. We notified our server so they offered lobster chow mein in replacement.  Bad idea, there was a big dead fly in the chow mein. I'm never coming here again!
author: lala l.

description: Good alternative to Hong Kong lounge that is always crowded. The place is close and is a lot cheaper. I normally come for the cheap dim sum. The ordering of dim sum is similar where you get a paper and order what you want. This place doesn't have carts. The food is quick and the service is like other dim sum restaurants. They also have a cool fountain in the back.
author: Jason L.

description:
Miss the cheap(er) dim sum in a restaurant environment rather than take out? I'm not even sure if you can still get it cheap at to-go places, either! 

This place is a solid go-to place. They have dishes that range from $2.25, $3.25, $3.75, and $5.25. The $5.25 one is usually the one that only some people find tasty, so you don't really have to worry. The thing to go with here is definitely the steamed churng fun (I prefer either the shrimp, meat, or fish fillet one... Wasn't too crazy about the bbq) The churng fun can have more stuffing in them, but the noodles are nice are soft, fresh in my opinion compared to some other dim sum places! Aside from the churng funs, go with anything shrimp. I usually don't like the ha gao, BUT for some reason theirs taste good!! I think it's because they actually de-vein (poop) the shrimp so it doesn't feel as yeucky. Their shrimps are nice and crunchy. They also have a deal with their lobster sauce noodles which was decent and flavorful for the 10-15 bucks they charge you. Their lobster tastes fresh and its meat is sweet! 

I'm not a huge fan of their steamed chicken feet (even though it's my all time favorite at any dim sums), but it just doesn't taste as fresh and their sauce/ marinate is meh. 

This place isn't the hoo ha of all dim sums, but it's good. It looks jenky and there's seatings when you walk past the kitchen area... which is a bit stinky and possibly unsanitary, but meh! No food is good unless it feels like it's a hole in the wall!  The bathroom is upstairs and decently clean... BUT hopefully you're not too tall because the ceiling is probably only about 6'5" high! Lol
author: Johanna T.

description:
It's only $2 a plate on weekdays, but even that doesn't draw me in as much as it should. The main reason for coming here is that it has a pretty interior, is usually stark empty, and that everything is super clean.

Good chinese food should not be this clean. Good dim sum should come on a cart. But alas, this place serves its purpose of filling my belly.

And yet WHY DON'T THEY HAVE FRIED TARO?
author: Colleen M.

description:
This place sucks. 

Old decor.
Service sucks.
Dirty plates, utensils, plates the food come out in.
Quality is absurdly subpar. 

If you enjoy this dim sum, you have really horrible taste and I'm really sad for you.
Heh
author: Robin D.

description: Really disappointing.  The shrimp dumplings were not edible.  The pot stickers were okay, though way too greasy. We won't be back.
author: Bonnie M.

description:
Here's another cool weekday-cheap dim sum joint.  The place is a lot bigger than it looks as they have a nice room in the back.  The service was pretty good too.  A minor annoyance eating there was the strong smell of incense permeating the whole restaurant....made me feel kinda nauseous and morbid like I was eating at a funeral.  Plenty of old folks eat here too which is a good thing since old folks know their dim sum. =)

Tip 1: They sell their $2, $2.50, and $3 plates at $1.90 on weekdays.

Tip 2: They have 3 different types of Shrimp dumpling.  The one that is the most common for dim sum is called House Steamed Shrimp Dumplings on their menu.

Tip 3: They have plenty on non-translated items on their menu and whiteboard so you'll need to ask or bring someone that knows how to read Chinese.

My Dim Sum Rating System:
Fried Egg Custard Buns=3
Pan Fried Pot Stickers=3
Rice noodle roll w/ beef=5
Rice noodle roll w/ shrimp=5
Shrimp Dumpling=4 *
Steamed Beef Balls=3
Steamed Chicken Feet=4
Steamed Shanghai Dumplings=2
Turnip Cake Fired w/ XO Sauce=5

* Didn't get a chance to try their House Steamed Shrimp Dumpling
author: B F.

description: had a light lunch here on a random weekend... was just ok. we ordered a few typical things, such as siu mai, har gao, lo bok go, etc. and all were pretty good/typical. what turned me off was they placed our foil-wrapped chicken on the table, then five minutes later came and back took it away to give to another table -___- we hadnt eaten any of it yet because we were still working on the other dishes, but this was the last thing that we ordered, and we ended up leaving because we didn't want to wait for the new order to come out. not very professional, but also not very surprising, as this was a typical chinese-run place. might be back since its so close to my house, and if we were too late to snag a table at hong kong lounge....
author: Sabrina L.

description: Wow. Almost an hour to get my order of fried rice and potstickers! Worker gave my order without saying anything. No sorry or thank you. Stay clear from this place. Bad service, unfriendly staff.
author: Elmer P.

description:
I came here with my dad a few weeks ago. the food is awesome and the service is what you would expect for 2-3 dollar plates.  I had the pop stickers, dumplins, pork buns, sprinp balls (awesome), and a whole lot of other plates.  My father and I just walked in and got seated on the spot.  I've to other Dim Sum spots like the popular one in Alameda.  Golden Gate is far better than the one I've been to in Alameda and the reviews they had were pretty high.  IT'S DIM SUM PEOPLE!!!! SIMPLE FOOD!!! IT DOESN'T HAVE TO HAVE A FAT PRICE TAG AND SERVERS IN FANCY SUITS.

over all, good food and well worth the 30 minute drive from my place.
author: Francisco F.

description:
Pretty solid Dim Sum. There are so many great places around the area that sometimes some of the Dim Sum places are not as memorable. This place is pretty okay but nothing too special. Service was a little slow and it wasn't the cleanest place to eat. 

Our party ordered a good assortment of dishes and they do have a great selection of Dim Sum, which is something I really appreciate about most of the Dim Sum joints in the area. 

Overall, great value, but I wish I could say something more remarkable!
author: Tracy Joy K.

description: It's just one of a few dim sum places in the Richmond district ,and one of the better ones too. Warm food, visually appealing, tasty, clean, nice service, and affordable! I've eaten here breakfast, lunch, and dinner; and it's all good. If you grew up liking dim sum, you'll like this place. Regular price is just ~2$ a plate and +.25 when its the weekend, awesome. A must get is the Har Gow, they have such soft skins, and not too sticky like many other places, and they don't break as easy as other places.
author: Mimi H.

description:
This review is just based on dinner only.

1.  Your homemade tofu is RIDICULOUSLY awesome.  So good and almost always sold out by the time my butt gets in there for dinner, but I try.  JUST ASK!

2.  You have a website that lets you order to go and totals everything up for you and applies any discounts or freebies.  How advanced is this for a Chinese restaurant???

Not the most amazing food; but decent/good Chinese food, really nice people running the place, easy to park and get a table on a weeknight.  

But really, JUST GET THE TOFU!
author: Christine K.

description:
This place is so near where I live, I just had to try it out.  After reading many reviews online I was curious to see if it was good like some raved about, or just soso like many others have said.

Upon arrival on a weekday day, I was quite surprised how packed it was.  The entire restaurant was full (including the back room near the garden).  The clientele was about 90% Chinese which was a good sign, and there was even a line.

We were seated rather quickly though, in about 5 minutes as there were 2 groups of 2 in front of us.  

The ambiance was quite nice.  I do like the decor and if you can sit by the garden in the back it's more bright and somewhat airy.  The restaurant at lunch as a lively and bustling feel, and probably is a bit more noisy than quiet.  But to me that was a plus as it gave it a "happening" feel.

As for food.  Many reviewers have said it's just "good" and I'll have to agree.  The food came out rather slow, and the taste/freshness was just a good (maybe 3.5 on scale of 5).  The one good thing about the food is it is hot, so it does seem to come straight from the kitchen.

Service was fast, and I know many have complained about poor service but to be honest we found the service speedy and attentive.  If you need something simply call the wait staff, as they are quite busy when it's during lunch time.  Some of the wait staff didn't have fluent English, but wasn't a problem for us as we spoke Chinese with them.

Lastly there were complaints about bathrooms being nasty.  I think it's a bit overblown.  Surely it's not super clean like you'd find in a 5 star restaurant, but no worse than a typical Chinese restaurant.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
Rude service (Ruder than normal for a Chinese restaurant). Waitresses do not apologize when they knock into you or when the spill water on your back. They also mug at you when you check on the dessert you ordered 20min ago and snap that it's being prepared. 

Allows smokers in back outside area which disturbs people dining in back room because every time the wind picks up, smoke flies though the vent above door and straight into the faces of those facing that way. 

Dim sum is so-so, the BBQ pork bun has a strange taste. Twice in the recent times we've been here, someone found hair in their dim sum. 

On the bright side, the restroom was very clean.
author: A. Z.

description: Not only were they very rude to me but the food gave me food poisoning which advanced to a bowel obstruction and plagued me for weeks. I have never felt the need to review anything on YELP but because of the severity of my situation I felt it necessary. DO NOT GO HERE!! Especially if you are not of Asian decent.
author: Connor S.

description: This is an authentic Chinese restaurant, mostly patronized by Asians. Some of the items on the menu will not appeal to Anglos, but the dishes we had were fresh and excellent. Clams with Black Bean Sauce and the House Steamed Shrimp Dumplings were superb!
author: Anne H.

description:
This place is not bad.  The siu mai was very fresh and their har gow had the right consistency, not gooey, like other dim sum places.  We ordered their fried shrimp to see if it was similar to the dish we love at Koi Palace.  The shrimp was ok, but definitely not like the dish at Koi.  Their XO noodles were good.  Peppered short rib was ok.  We also ordered steamed scallop dumplings but they gave us fried scallops instead.  The waitress tried to charge us for the mistake but we insisted they take the dish back and remove it from our bill.  They also didn't have fried taro dumpling which my fiance loves.  We thought that was odd for a dim sum place.

Overall, we thought the dim sum here tasted fresh.  It's not the best place to have dim sum (Koi Palace is still our fave), but for the prices, it's not too bad.
author: V B.

description:
3/19/08 Update:

Ok we finally got around to having dinner here.  We did take out and we also ate in.  

Take out:  We ordered Peking pork chop, tofu sole hot pot, green beans and green onion chicken. That qualified us for free delivery.  

Delivery was fast and food came out hot.  Food was pretty good.  Portions are a bit on the small side.  Would do take out again.

Eat in Dinner:  After testing out their dinner food, I made reservations for a table in the patio room for a family dinner.  This was an early dinner (5:30).  The hostess the reservation wasn't a problem.  

However, when we got there, they told us that a bunch of people (who's been eating since 2 PM!?!?) is still squatting on our reserved table.  They did not have the heart or were gutless to kick these losers out of our table.  Upon inspection, those people weren't even eating.  They were squatting at the table chit chatting (how to ya like that?).  

The other tables in the patio room were reserved for other people at 7 (huh, we came at 5:30, how come we can't have one of those?  We're super fast eaters!) so they didn't want to offer those tables to us.  The waiter offered the ones in the front room but my folks complained about the room being drafty (it is cold w/ the door opening and closing).  

Finally, they made a makeshift table of 10 for us in the hallway connecting the front room to the patio room (the hallway were tables of 4 are located).  Unfortunately, that meant we were squeezed together in the table cuz one side of the table is flushed against a wall (so no on can sit there!).  They also gave us a bum lazy susan that literally moves across the table when you spin it!.

Really for all our discomfort and inconvenience (remember, we had a reservation!), you'd think they'd give us a discount or throw in some free food. Nada.  We got zilch!  They just apologized and said we'll make it up to you next time.  Really, I don't know how you're gonna make it up to us since there's no documentation of what ya did and you didn't promise a free dish or anything like that!

Food was ok but on the small portioned side.

Oh yeah, we finished and left before that 7:00 PM reservation for the remaining patio room tables arrived.  So ya see, we would have vamoosed it before anyone showed up.  We have some consideration!

Those damn squatters on our reserved table were still sitting around and NOT EATING by the time we left.

Based on the poor dinner service, I'm deducting a star (I'm being generous too!).  Come here for the dim sum.  Don't come here for dinner.

*********************************

I heard about this new restaurant via Chowhound so I decided to take the parents for lunch here.  This is a little bit off Clement St (a couple of  blocks past Park Presidio to be exact, between 19th & 20th Avenue).

Restaurant is very spacious and clean.  They sat us in the back, indoor patio section.  There's a real nice koi filled fountain beyond the patio that you can go out and look at the Koi.  Several of the patrons actually went out and got a smoke there.

There are no carts.  Service is given via a check list.  I prefer this because the food comes out hot.  Dim sum is excellent.  My folks raved about how the Chicken Feet were the best they've had in a long time.  That's saying something cuz they always complained about the chicken feet.

We also ordered a plate of vegetarian chow mein.  That was pretty yummy too.

The food was done just right.  Not too salty.

Service was excellent.  The staff checked back to see how you were doing and you were profusely thanked on your way out the door.

Dim sum prices $2-$4.50.  Pretty reasonable considering the Banquet costs a bit more and food is mediocre at best.

This isn't just a dim sum house because they serve dinner too.  Based on the menu, I'd say the prices are pretty good.  Gotta go back to eat dinner here one of these days.

Parking is the only thing that sucks.  It's very difficult to find parking although I noticed they had the front of their restaurant marked off for customers so I guess if you have a big party, they'd save you 2 spots.

Go ahead, check it out.  Not a bad place to have dim sum!
author: Wendy H.

description:
This place sucks. Bad food and bad service.
It took them forever to get us the fried noodle. We finally got the noodle when we were about to leave and the noodle was BURNED. I asked the server why it was burned and her reply was, "It is supposed to be like that." Was she an idiot or she thought we were idiots???
Will never go back again, not even for free.
author: carrie H.

description:
I went to GGDS based on a review I read in the Examiner
http://www.sfexaminer.com/entertainment/2011/05/authentic-cantonese-dining-golden-gate-dim-sum

I found the review to be inaccurate. I thought that the food would be great. It was OK. I even brought Chinese speaking friends as the review suggested. My Chinese friends will not let me suggest Chinese restaurants anymore. 

Notables - The steamed spare ribs were tasty but there wasn't enough meat on the bone. The oxtail stew was really good. The service was fast and attentive. They let me squat at a table for 30 minutes until my friends arrived (late). There was definitely a language barrier at some points but they were patient with me and tried to communicate.

The experience was good enough but I will not return.
author: Kiristen R.

description:
Golden Gate Dim Sum is definitely off the scale! One bite makes me want to travel back in time to the very instant I thought this was going to be a great lunch. 
Greeeaaattt.... Every fish we bit into had egg sacks. Were these caught during the grunion run?
Greeeaaattt.... Honey, this restaurant scored an 89. Uh oh!
Greeeaaattt.... I think I've cleaned out my colon! FOOD POISON FREE IS THE WAY TO BE. Enjoy!
author: BORAMEY H.

description:
i came here  with some old coworkers, new coworkers, and new friends for lunch today.  I liked that even though it was on Clement it wasnt as crowded and there was actually parking in front of the place.  

we got in and were seated right away.  like most dim sum places we got a list that had $2/$2.50/$3 plates.  Nancy did all the ordering and Tu added some...when they said they were gonna order alot, they weren't kidding.

I tried everything from what must've been at least 30 plates.  My faves were the stuffed eggplant w/shrimp and the shrimp rice noodle rolls...i was stuffed and there was so much left order and it's cheap!! definitely gotta come back here!!

i heard that on the weekdays all dim sum is $2!!
author: Ray R.

description:
Went on a weekday.  Although the menu that they give you to mark down your dim sum choices show three prices ($2, $2.50, $3), all dishes are actually $2.25.  I wish I had known that earlier,...I would have picked more $3 dishes!  
My barometer for dim sum is always a restaurant's siu mai.  Theirs was not very good.  The shanghai dumplings were also disappointing.  They were thick, doughy, and not soupy at all.  Service was also slow, and food was slow getting out.  I think I'll try another restaurant next time I want dim sum.
author: PJ C.

description: Excellent dimsum : pan fried crispy taro cake , shrimp  rice noodles , bean curd skin roll with shrimp , stuffed eggplant, stuffed green peppers , flavorful pea shoot dumplings ....all fresh and inexpensively priced .  Good pleasant service .
author: Cynthia Y.

description:
I come here quite often with my family for weekday dim-sum.  Small Medium Large dishes are all only $2!  And, they don't charge extra for tea per person like most dim sum places!  

Is it my favorite place for dim sum in the city? Probably not. But, there's hardly ever a wait for this place and it's cheap. Parking isn't too miserable. There's certainly certain dim sum that are more consistently tasty than others.  And, they do make their dim sum when it's ordered on the sheet, so it's never cold!  

I do highly recommend steam BBQ buns, the sticky rice wrapped in lotus leaves, shrimp stuffed with eggplant, and the steam rice noodle with shrimp and the one with beef.     

Min $20 for credit card
author: stephanie c.

description:
For one of the oldest Chinese communities in the United States, I don't understand why the gene pool has been such a disappointment in SF.  Hence, I don't venture out when I can do mediocre in my kitchen.  But when it comes to dim sum, since I don't plan to be pumpin' out dan-ta or ha-gao out my Pac Heights studio, I can be convinced to mingle with my countrymen.  Next time, it probably won't be at Golden Gate Dim Sum unless I only have ten dollar bill in my pocket.  For being hella cheap, it's okay. 

On the dishes: turnip cake was mushy, ha-gao and other dumplings were okay, but stuck together, deep fried dumplings were off (skin v. filling proportions), shrimp rice noodle were off (skin v. filling proportions), dan-ta were okay, and steamed pork buns were a thumbs up.
author: Wendy L.

description:
if you want to feel like youre in a sauna while attempting to eat, then come here.  it was such a cold night that i never could figure how a restaurant SF could get that hot!  Even my cuzzos n I were taking rounds of going outside to cool off.. 

lets face it, it is nicer looking than most Chinese restaurants in SF, but when it comes to food (dinner) and the lack of air circulation, it was barely 3 stars. 

now down to the food:
1. jellyfish appetizer- decent
2. steamed fish- uhh...overcooked
3. peking duck w/bun- bunz seemed like they were microwaved n left out for awhile; inedible piece of rock.
4. beans w/beef- decent
5. chicken w/garlic and oil- good
6. my great grandma's 100th bday cake- THE BEST PART...which came from a bakery.
author: Kimberly C.

description: One of the worst restaurant experiences I have ever had. I was over charged initially, and asked to see my itemized bill. The cashier over charged us by over $20. Everyone makes mistakes no problem, but to have her charge our cards for more then the bill was, was clearly on purpose. When we asked why she charged us more then the amount stated on the bill, the cashier threw change at us to accommodate the fact she rounded up the bill yet again. This is no way to run a business or treat your customers. I highly recommend taking your business else where.
author: Cara G.

description: The food is good, but the service is trash. I can't believe this. He just pretend not to see us. I even had to yell in order for him to come. I need walk up to order or hand over the orders or else wait for like 10 minutes for him to care. The worse service I have ever seen in my life in a restaurant!
author: Jason C.

description:
This is for the general public. When I heated up the second half of my chicken entre (Chicken with Scallions) and began to separate the "morsels" of chicken from the rice, and the meat from the bones, the shape of one "morsel" of chicken seemed "troublesome."   **** It was the head of the chicken, beak and all.****  Maybe it is squeamish of me, a wimpy westerner, to not want to find the head of the bird in my bowl, but I will not be ordering from here again, or setting foot inside the door of the place. 
________________________________________________________________
Took a gamble on trying to order on-line Chinese delivery from a new place. Their on-line menu said 2 free cans of soda with order of 20.00 or more. My first attempt at ordering came to about 21 bucks and their automated system said the discount would not apply. "OK," I thought, I will get a higher-priced entre, so that the order will be over 20 dollars BEFORE taxes. When I did that, their on-line system honored the discount and my bill and receipt clearly indicated that two free cans of soda were included in my order.  Then I called the restaurant since there was no where on the menu to choose what kind of soda.  Restaurant said they don't offer that deal unless the order is over 25 dollars. I got no soda as advertised, and the main course (chicken) was cold when it arrived.
author: Philip R.

description:
Food: 2.5/5
I've been here a few times now and have to say the food has always been pretty good but at the same time scary because from what other yelpers have said is that it can be pretty dirty too. Now I've never gotten sick off the food and don't think many other people have or this place wouldn't be that busy. There are many dim sum restaurants all over the city and yes you can find better but this is still pretty good. 

Atmosphere: 4/5
I think the atmosphere in there is pretty nice. There are multiple levels and the back room is pretty cool because it faces a little private garden with a pond(ish) setup; albeit it does need a little maintenance but Chinese restaurants are infamous for not changing their decor.

Service:2.5/5
Well it's dim sum and the servers are rushed and have everyone yelling at them so I don't expect too much of them. Luckily I had someone who spoke both Cantonese and Mandarin with me so it made it that much easier. 

Price: 4/5
Dim sum is expectedly cheap and this place meets the standard. 

That something special: 3/5
The thing that really hit the right note for me this time was the interior, but I usually want the something special to be the food, nonetheless I was pleased with my experience.

Total: 3.2/5
author: Aaron P.

description: We had a very hard time getting what we ordered.   Then they messed up the check.   The quality of the the items were average at best,  but we didn't order them.   Customer service is an area they need to wrork on.   Wanted to give them the benefit of the doubt but couldn't due to rudeness.  Too many other options to choose from when it comes to these types of restaurants.   That was my first and last visit.
author: Peter G.

description:
The cousins we were visiting decided that it would be too long of a wait on a Saturday to go to the dim sum place originally planned in this same neighborhood. We mentioned that two nights earlier we had a very nice dinner here and saw that they had a dim sum service. So we reserved two tables here for the "clan." Each table ordered their own selections without consultation across the tables. So we each wound up with pretty much what Yelper Teri C. ordered (below) plus a few other things that one or more at the table liked (a tureen of village congee, stuffed rice noodle rolls, and shrimp stuffed eggplant, included at our table.) 

Also, the dim sum menu is printed in English, so I don't understand one Yelper's problem with not reading Chinese. As other Yelpers have mentioned, the bill was pretty thrifty for a group this large. And the best thing was we all enjoyed what was served (everything was fresh and well-made), leaving almost nothing to take home. Luckily there was a healthy walk following all of this consumption!
author: Weisun C.

description: Very cheap and food is ok. Staff are not attentive. Very slow service. Bathrooms were unhygienic. Dessert came out before hot dishes. Will not come back. Great eastern on Jackson street is so much better. Better to pay a bit more and get good quality and fast service
author: Matthew H.

description:
4.5 stars.
WOW. Seriously good dim sum! We stumbled upon this place on Sunday afternoon at 2 pm when everywhere else was either too crowded or just done with dim sum, and boy and I glad we did. Off the beaten path, no crowds, no ticket numbers, no waiting, no carts of cold food. Order by check mark and all your dishes are prepared so fresh that they are actually too hot to eat right away, extremely fresh. The crispy items are wonderfully crispy and not dry at all. Nothing was greasy, tough, too dense, uneven, or meh. Everything was damn good. Clean, fresh, good textures, and VERY affordable! Very polite waitstaff to, especially for Chinese restaurant standards.
author: Thlel Yan D.

description: service sucks, called in on a sunday to make a reservation, they claimed that they don't take reservations on sundays. No big deal.. i can wait... tick tock.. tick tock.. ok an hour goes by and finally a table opens up and gets cleaned off. we were just about to go sit and this lady sits there, we complain to the waitress and she states that she called ahead.. WTF??! whatever, were not going to start an argument because all the family is here and it's suppose to be a good day. So we order our food, takes forever and nothing was too memorable, typical dim sum. Probably not going to be returning to this place, so many other better dim sum places.
author: Lily S.

description:
This is by far one of the worst tea houses I've been to. I had to come here because I was invited to but if it were up to me, I wouldn't have come. They don't have  a large variety of dim sum to choose from and their service, no offense, is somewhat crappy. When we arrived, we were missing napkins and it took them quite a while just to accommodate that. In addition, it takes them a long time just to refill our tea kettles... A lot of their food seems to lack color, making them unappealing to eat. For example, their sponge cake is usually a rich golden or brown color to indicate the brown sugar used to make it; their sponge cake is colorless. My favorite steamed beef tripes were looked as though it was just slapped on to a plate and served. They were unnecessarily large in size, hard and the soy sauce was watered down. Their pan fried XO white carrot cubes looked more like salt and pepper fried white carrot cubes.
Quite frankly, I will never come back to have dim sum here. Their dinner service however, is actually better, I think, but it's been a year since I came here for dinner.
author: Judy C.

description:
Food is good.
Price is great.
Service is fair.

Try it out : )
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Went to this restaurant with my friends since Hong Kong Lounge was packed with the usual Saturday crowds and we were craving for dim sum. Just a little note that they charge extra $0.50 per plate for dim sum during dinner hours. 

The dim sum was okay, not great... Definitely not as good as HK Lounge... For example, the egg yolk buns  did not have the 'oozing' effect when you split the bun in half and the Shanghai dumplings (xiao long bao) were pretty dry; there was no soup/ juice when you bite into the skin.. We did enjoy the steamed pork buns and the steamed sweet cake though. 

The quality of service was below my expectations. I have to admit their service was prompt but their warped logic was a little too much for us... We actually ordered steamed pork buns and they served us chicken buns, telling us that 'oh, these are chicken buns in replacement of the pork buns.' and left. We were baffled, thinking that they probably ran out of steamed pork buns and hence the replacement.. but they didn't check with us if we wanted the replacement (which a usual restaurant would if they ran out of something, no?). So I asked if they ran out of steamed pork buns. I was stunned by their reply -- "Oh we steamed the wrong buns so we gave you the chicken buns. You stand to gain since the chicken buns are actually more expensive than the pork buns and we are only charging you for the price of the pork buns...." This makes perfect sense, doesn't it? And she actually said it matter-of-factly... We decided to place another order of steamed pork buns and yes, we were charged for that too (on top of the wrong chicken buns) but we made up for it by giving a tip which they 'rightfully deserve'...
author: Evelyn L.

description:
A-OK dim sum indeed. Not the best or worst I've ever had, but definitely the cheapest (with the exception of take-out style).

I was raised eating dim sum every other Saturday with my family. That tradition dissolved once I left for college. I still try to eat dim sum with my family any chance I get. Took my mom here this past Monday, where there was no crowd, but a rather consistent flow of elderly folks. 

Main downside is that you order by marking off a menu, which is hard for people like me and my mom, who don't speak/read/understand Chinese. All these years I've relied on pointing at stuff on carts. Tried my best to equate the English descriptions to dishes I was familiar with. Lucked out on 4 out of 5 items. The mushroom tofu roll was definitely not what I was expecting, so I wouldn't order that again.

When the bill arrived I went WTF. $10.80 for 2 people??? That's less than $2 per dish. Maybe that's what that sign on the door was referring to. It was all in Chinese characters so I had no clue there was some cheap deal going on. Best bargain bite in town!
author: Victoria N.

description:
Really Great Prices for Dim Sum!  Small, Middle, Big and House Special Prices are $2, $2.50, $3 and $4.50, respectively.  And the Food was pretty good on my visit.  No complaints at all.  Nothing there was really not good.  To me, everything was at or above average.  I especially liked their tripe.  Big portion and you could tell it was really fresh as it had that certain texture I really like when I eat tripe.  

The only thing we thought was a little off was their soy sauce.  It seemed like it was less flavorful than usual.  Not sure if it was low sodium but maybe for the better since Dim Sum is generally not really healthy for you in the first place.
